TEXT.P: The point where the immigration and extinction curves intersect is the number of species expected to be on the island.

When there are fewer species, immigration exceeds extinction and the number of species should increase. When there are more species, extinction exceeds immigration and the number of species should decrease.
In other words, the intersection represents the equilibrium number of species on the island.
Modify the immigration and extinction rates, then move the vertical line over the intersection point to see the number of species expected to be on your hypothetical island.
